trial_identification.studytitle: Melatonin vs. placebo for the symptoms of delirium in elderly medical inpatients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A double blinded, randomised, placebo controlled pilot trial of moderate dose melatonin for the abatement and treatment of delirium in elderly general medical inpatients.

interventions.interventions: Melatonin 5mg oral capsule nightly for 5 days administered directly by hospital nursing staff.
interventions.comparator: Placebo - identical capsule but for active ingredient.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Symptoms of delirium - Memorial Delirium Assessment Scale.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Average during treatment assessed daily over the 5 day treatment period.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Symptoms of delirium - Memorial Delirium Assessment Scale.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Following treatment cessation, on days 6 and 7 of the trial (medication on days 1-5)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of delirium (regardless of cause) Inpatient under general medicine of the The Royal Melbourne Hospital
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusively hypoactive delirium, recent stroke (<14 days), sensory impairment or dysphasia or language such that not evaluable, undergoing surgery, prognosis <7days, severe hepatic or renal failure, allergy or intolerance to melatonin or excipients.

trial_design.concealment: Permuted block opaque envelopes with random allocation by trial pharmacist

recruitment.hospital: Royal Melbourne Hospital - City campus - Parkville

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is a pilot trial testing the feasibility and participants required to test the hypothesis that melatonin 5mg capsule every night will decrease the symptoms of delirium in elderly medical inpatients.
